p._value:
openssl-c_rehash,
openssl-rehash, c_rehash, rehash - Create symbolic links to
files named by the hash values

_values:
On some
platforms, the OpenSSL

command is available as
an external script called

. They are
functionally equivalent, except for minor differences noted
below.

p._value:
scans directories and calculates a hash value of each
".pem", ".crt", ".cer", or
".crl" file in the specified directory list and
creates symbolic links for each file, where the name of the
link is the hash value. (If the platform does not support
symbolic links, a copy is made.) This utility is useful as
many programs that use OpenSSL require directories to be set
up like this in order to find certificates.

_values:
If any
directories are named on the command line, then those are
processed in turn. If not, then the

environment variable is
consulted; this should be a colon-separated list of
directories, like the Unix

variable. If that is not set then the default directory
(installation-specific but often
) is processed.

p._value:
In order for a
directory to be processed, the user must have write
permissions on that directory, otherwise an error will be
generated.

_values:
The links
created are of the form "HHHHHHHH.D", where each
is a hexadecimal character and

is a single
decimal digit. When processing a directory,

will first remove all links that have a name in that syntax,
even if they are being used for some other purpose. To skip
the removal step, use the
flag. Hashes for
’s look similar except the letter

appears after the period, like this:
"HHHHHHHH.rD".

Multiple
objects may have the same hash; they will be indicated by
incrementing the

value. Duplicates are found by
comparing the full

fingerprint. A
warning will be displayed if a duplicate is found.

A warning will
also be displayed if there are files that cannot be parsed
as either a certificate or a

or if more
than one such object appears in the file.
The
script uses the

program
to compute the hashes and fingerprints. If not found in the
user’s
, then set the

environment variable to the
full pathname. Any program can be used, it will be invoked
as follows for either a certificate or

$OPENSSL x509
-hash -fingerprint -noout -in FILENAME
$OPENSSL crl -hash -fingerprint -noout -in FILENAME
where

is the filename. It must
output the hash of the file on the first line, and the
fingerprint on the second, optionally prefixed with some
text and an equals sign.
Use old-style hashing (
as opposed to

Generate links for both
old-style (
) and new-style (

) hashing. This allows releases before
1.0.0 to use these links along-side newer releases.

p._value:
The path to an executable to
use to generate hashes and fingerprints (see above).

Colon separated list of
directories to operate on. Ignored if directories are listed
on the command line.

p._value:
Do not remove existing links. This is needed when
keeping new and old-style links in the same directory.

_values:
Print messages about old links removed and new links
created. By default,

only lists each directory
as it is processed.
